author: By Stanley Reed
title: Angola to Quit OPEC in Dispute Over Oil Production Levels
description: Officials have been unhappy after the oil cartel, led by Saudi Arabia, pushed Angola and other countries to accept lower production ceilings.
content: In a sign of lingering tensions among oil producers, Angola said Thursday that the country would be leaving OPEC. The decision was made at a cabinet meeting led by President Joao Lourenco, the state-owned Jornal de Angola reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Feeding a Crowd on Christmas Morning
description: Including an overnight French toast casserole to mercilessly douse in maple syrup.
content: There are many moments that, upon a bit of reflection, feel like the demarcation between childhood and adulthood. Maybe it’s when you finally recycled all of those construction paper crafts from elementary school that your parents hoarded in your childhood home. Or perhaps it’s when you first brought a partner to your family’s Thanksgiving, a one-way ticket from the kids’ table to the grown-ups’.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Climate Forward Team
title: Share the Climate-Related Pop Culture That Stuck With You
description: The Climate Forward team wants to hear about climate-focused books, art, film, TV and music that moved you in 2023.
content: 2023: a year when climate change felt inescapable, and a year when climate change started to feel ubiquitous in popular culture. In this week’s Climate Forward newsletter, we listed the climate culture pieces that resonated with us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Way Up on a Mountain
description: David Steinberg opens our solving weekend with a fun puzzle and some news.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Man Accused of Ramaswamy Death Threat Is Charged With Threatening Christie
description: Tyler Anderson of New Hampshire was charged on Wednesday with threatening the lives of Chris Christie and another unnamed presidential candidate.
content: A New Hampshire man who was charged with threatening to kill Vivek Ramaswamy and his supporters at a campaign event has been indicted by a federal grand jury with additional counts for threatening the lives of former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, another unnamed presidential candidate and other people, according to an indictment filed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Raymond Dirks, Whose Tipster Case Redefined Insider Trading, Dies at 89
description: In a far-reaching decision, the Supreme Court restored him from censured analyst to whistle-blower in a major corporate fraud.
content: Raymond L. Dirks, a maverick Wall Street analyst who was accused of insider trading by securities regulators but then vindicated by the U.S. Supreme Court as a whistle-blower in a major fraud, died on Dec. 9 in Manhattan. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Rite Aid’s A.I. Facial Recognition Wrongly Tagged People of Color as Shoplifters
description: Under the terms of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission, the pharmacy chain will be barred from using the technology as a surveillance tool for five years.
content: Rite Aid, the pharmacy chain, used facial recognition technology to falsely and disproportionately identify people of color and women as likely shoplifters, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday, describing a system that embarrassed customers and raised new concerns about the biases baked into such technologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Omid Scobie’s ‘Endgame’ Heralds the Start of a New Era
description: Having written about an inflection point for the British monarchy, the royals chronicler is at a crossroads in his own career.
content: December has been a momentous month for Omid Scobie, the British journalist who is best known for his coverage of the royal family. Not only did “Endgame,” his second book about palace intrigue, debut at No. 12 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Scobie also learned that a judge ruled in Prince Harry’s favor in a lawsuit against a phone-hacking tabloid publisher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Fetterman, Breaking With the Left on Israel, Rejects ‘Progressive’ Label
description: The Pennsylvania senator, who has angered liberal Democrats with his staunchly pro-Israel stance and position on immigration, assailed the left and said he no longer considers himself a progressive.
content: In April 2022, during his Senate primary campaign in Pennsylvania, John Fetterman spoke enthusiastically about his unqualified support for Israel and said he did not consider himself a “progressive” when it came to his views on the Jewish state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Do You Enjoy Keeping Secrets?
description: How good are you at holding on to information, especially about yourself?
content: Can I tell you a secret? Do you promise not to tell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The U.S. Is Looking to Use Russian Assets to Aid Ukraine
description: Also, the U.S. and Egypt negotiate over aid to Gaza. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: The Biden administration has quietly signaled support for seizing more than $300 billion in Russian central bank assets held in Western countries and using the funds to aid Ukraine’s war effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Thursday Briefing
description: Peace talks in Cairo and at the U.N..
content: In Cairo and at the U.N., talks about a possible truce between Israel and Hamas over the war in the Gaza Strip are making slow progress, as negotiators struggled to come up with plans for pausing the fighting, freeing hostages and speeding up help for Gazans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samer Sinijlawi
title: Mahmoud Abbas Must Go
description: Thirty years after the Oslo Accords, the Palestinians who led the first intifada feel they have been betrayed.
content: I got into politics when I was 15, joining Fatah Youth in Jerusalem during the first intifada in 1987. Several years later, and with other young Fatah leaders, I met Mahmoud Abbas in his office in Ramallah, West Bank. He was the No. 2 in the Palestine Liberation Organization back then. He was in his 50s; we were in our 20s. Despite the age gap, we always enjoyed spending time with him. “You are tomorrow’s leaders,” he would tell us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Clarence Thomas Threatened to Resign Over Salary Concerns in 2000
description: The justice set off a scramble by a lawmaker to find a way to raise his pay.
content: Justice Clarence Thomas pressed congressional lawmakers for a higher salary early in his tenure on the Supreme Court, threatening to resign and inspiring a campaign by Republican backers to meet his demands, according to a memo addressed to the chief justice in June 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Court Ruling May Revive Plan for Soccer Super League in Europe
description: The European Court of Justice said the sport’s governing bodies had abused their dominant position by blocking a new competition, opening the way for revamped proposals.
content: An effort to to create a new soccer Super League that collapsed so spectacularly within 48 hours in 2021 has been given new life after Europe’s top court ruled on Thursday that the sport’s governing bodies were “abusing a dominant position” when they shot down the plans for the new competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: ‘I Left Him Behind’: Freed Hostage Fears for Father, Still in Gaza
description: Sahar Kalderon, 16, spent 52 days as a hostage. She says she cannot enjoy her freedom until her father, Ofer, is free.
content: In the 52 days that Sahar Kalderon, 16, spent as a hostage in Gaza, it was not only her captors who terrified her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: A Light Display With Many, but Not All, Glowing Reviews
description: In Union Vale, N.Y., Ronda Kaysen found that a home’s flashy holiday décor has been met with mixed reactions from neighbors.
content: In December 2020, I wrote a feel-good story for The New York Times’s Real Estate section about Americans going big on holiday lights during the Covid-19 pandemic. Among my examples was a family in Union Vale, N.Y., that held the Guinness World Record for the most lights on a residential property.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Whole Foods Wins Case About Black Lives Matter Apparel
description: An administrative judge ruled that the chain did not break the law by forbidding employees to wear apparel showing support for Black Lives Matter.
content: Whole Foods did not violate the law when it punished employees for wearing apparel supporting the Black Lives Matter movement, a federal administrative judge ruled on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Egill Bjarnason
title: Please Do Not Go Near the Volcanic Eruption, Iceland Asks Tourists
description: The government told people to “think four times” before embarking on a hike to view the eruption.
content: The authorities in Iceland on Thursday reiterated calls to tourists to avoid the site of a volcanic eruption, a spectacular show of spewing lava, after a hiker had to be rescued by helicopter earlier in the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: America Is Averting Its Eyes From Something Very, Very Wrong
description: Black and Hispanic youth use social media more than white kids, exposing them to its psychological harms and distracting from more useful endeavors.
content: For some people, social media is inconsequential — a cat photo here, a banana slip TikTok there. For others, it’s all-consuming — a helpless catapult into a slurry of anxiety, self-harm and depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suzy Hansen
title: We’re Beginning to Learn How the War on Terror Shaped a Generation
description: A generation of young people grew up experiencing increasingly scary and cascading crises set off by their government’s actions. Is it any wonder they’re protesting now?
content: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today. Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously. Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it. No one can confidently say who knew what when.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Real Women Have Curves’ and ‘Heart Sellers’: Snapshots of Immigrant Lives
description: A musical adaptation of “Curves” and a play about two Asian women becoming friends both look at immigrants’ experiences, with mixed results.
content: Body positivity was not at all the cultural vibe in 1990, when Josefina López’s play “Real Women Have Curves” was new. There was a rebelliousness to its climactic strip-down scene, in which a group of Latinas sewing dresses in a roasting-hot Los Angeles factory peel off layers of their clothing and shed a bit of shame, reveling in their lived-in bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Why Is Shari Redstone, Ruler of a Vast Media Kingdom, Weighing a Sale?
description: She fought to keep control of her family’s media empire. Now she’s considering an exit as financial pressures mount.
content: Paramount Pictures, the storied studio behind hits like “The Godfather” and “Raiders of the Lost Ark,” has had several owners over the last century: Its co-founder Adolph Zukor. The industrial conglomerate Gulf+Western. At one point, it was a stand-alone public company.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Two of our recommended books this week use fiction to delve into Korean history and its relation to America, to strikingly different effect: Ed Park’s novel “Same Bed Different Dreams” is a sprawling, exuberant confection rife with wordplay and shades of Thomas Pynchon or Don DeLillo, while Paul Yoon’s “The Hive and the Honey” is a pointillist collection of spare, evocative short stories whose power derives from their restraint. Taken together the contrast is bracing, like sea salt and caramel, but of course you can choose to read either one without the other; we serve all tastes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Wants to Run on Her Record, Not Her Gender
description: The Republican presidential candidate would be the first woman to enter the White House, but she has so far tried to avoid the identity politics that could repel some voters.
content: Inside the warehouse for an upscale department store chain in eastern Iowa, Michele Barton, wearing a white T-shirt emblazoned with “Women for Nikki” in bright pink letters, mused excitedly about the prospect of sending the first woman to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘All of Us Strangers’ Review: A Soul Longing for the Impossible
description: Playing a man alienated from himself and looking for answers, Andrew Scott makes this film sing.
content: Lonely suburban existence is filmmaker catnip, but urban apartment life — especially in new, soundproof buildings — can be just as isolating, maybe more. High in a box in the sky, it’s easy to fancy yourself the last person on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Amid Dismal Polling and Some Voter Anger, Don’t Expect Biden to Shift His Strategy
description: Officials in the president’s orbit say polls won’t change a strategy centered on comparing the Biden agenda with a Republican one, even as some allies feel betrayed by his policies.
content: For weeks, polls have shown President Biden trailing his likely challenger, former President Donald J. Trump. Protesters have streamed through Washington, demanding that Mr. Biden call for a cease-fire in Gaza. Groups of key voters, including young people and voters of color, have suggested that they might not support Mr. Biden in the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Rebel Moon — Part One: Child of Fire’ Review: Galaxy Brained
description: Zack Snyder creates a space opera that’s bloated but rarely buoyant.
content: Oddly, for a movie that’s rated PG-13 and often plays like a young-adult fantasy, Zack Snyder’s “Rebel Moon — Part One: A Child of Fire” features at least two attempted sexual assaults and a queasily erotic encounter between a shirtless man and a many-tentacled alien. The film’s most thorough violation, though, is of its cinematic bloodline: To call “Rebel Moon” a “Star Wars” pastiche — with a dash of “Dune,” a lick of “Lord of the Rings” and a whole heap of “Seven Samurai”— is both glaringly accurate and somewhat redundant. In today’s fantasy-verse, derivativeness is virtually a given. Snyder has long been open about his influences, and has been imagining this crossbreeding of mythologies since he was in college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Mapping the Lesser-Known Territories of American Modern Dance
description: An exhibition at New York Public Library tells a different, more inclusive story about the genealogy of an art form.
content: The creation of American modern dance, in the first half of the 20th century, was akin to the development of jazz or the Broadway musical, all potent new forms of expression for a country on the rise. Its history has often been framed as a simple genealogy of mavericks and rebels — almost all white — big personalities who commanded a lot of attention: Isadora Duncan and Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn begat Martha Graham and Doris Humphrey who begat Paul Taylor, Merce Cunningham and José Limón. “Border Crossings: Exile and American Modern Dance 1900-1955,” an exhibition at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts through March 16, tells quite a different story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: On Satanic Idols and Free Speech
description: An act of ideological vandalism offers a crucial lesson.
content: On Dec. 14, a Christian veteran named Michael Cassidy walked into the Iowa State Capitol and destroyed a display erected by the Satanic Temple of Iowa. The display was an idol of Baphomet, a robed figure with a goat head. Cassidy told Fox News host Jesse Watters that he had destroyed the statue in an act of “Christian civil disobedience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Migration’ Review: Is It a Road Trip if You Have Wings?
description: An animated feature written by Mike White (“The White Lotus”) stars Awkwafina, Elizabeth Banks and Kumail Nanjiani as birds, but it never fully gets off the ground.
content: Classic cartoon wisdom deems that ducks are brash and brazen creatures. See Donald and Daffy, ill-tempered anthropomorphic animals who aren’t afraid of making a display of their displeasure.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kathy Hourigan Is Retiring, but Not From Robert Caro
description: “Caro’s works are masterpieces of research and artistry,” says the former vice president and managing editor at Knopf Doubleday, who looks forward to — what else? — more reading, after 60 years on the job.
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: 2 Teens Convicted of Murder in Fatal Stabbing of Transgender Girl in England
description: A jury found that a boy and a girl, both now 16, murdered Brianna Ghey, 16, who was stabbed 28 times at a park near Manchester in February.
content: Two teenagers were found guilty on Wednesday of murdering Brianna Ghey, a 16-year-old transgender girl who was stabbed 28 times at a park in northwest England in February, local prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Harvard Finds More Instances of ‘Duplicative Language’ in President’s Work
description: Claudine Gay has faced growing criticism of not only her response to antisemitism on campus but also her scholarship.
content: Harvard University, in the face of mounting questions over possible plagiarism in the scholarly work of its president, Claudine Gay, said on Wednesday that it had found two additional instances of insufficient citation in her work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: New Jersey Deli Scheme Leads to Securities Fraud Guilty Plea
description: James T. Patten admitted to orchestrating misleading trades involving the deli’s parent company in an apparent bid to enrich himself and two co-defendants.
content: A man involved in a brazen plot to manipulate the stock price of a New Jersey deli’s parent company pleaded guilty to securities fraud on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dawn MacKeen
title: Do You Really Need That Antibiotic?
description: It’s antibiotic season. Brush up on how you should use them — and when to avoid them.
content: Chasing away an infection with the right antibiotic can feel magical.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Lawsuit Over Naked Baby on Nirvana’s ‘Nevermind’ Is Revived
description: The suit about the 1991 album had been dismissed because of the statute of limitations. But an appeals court ruled that it could proceed, noting that the album had been reissued in 2021.
content: A federal appeals court ruled against the grunge rock group Nirvana on Thursday, reviving a lawsuit about the band’s use of a naked baby on the cover of its 1991 album “Nevermind.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: Catching Up With the Rev. Cecil Williams, a San Francisco Legend
description: Williams made Glide Memorial Church in the Tenderloin world-famous.
content: There is only one place the Rev. Cecil Williams would think to spend Christmas Day: Glide Memorial Church in the Tenderloin neighborhood of San Francisco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Trump, the Voters and the Constitution
description: A clash between constitutional textualism and voter empowerment.
content: At its core, the Colorado lawsuit trying to keep Donald Trump off the 2024 ballot involves a clash between constitutional textualism and voter empowerment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez and Anna Foley
title: How Iowa Learned to Love Trump
description: Iowa’s Republican voters typically reward faith-driven candidates. That doesn’t look to be how 2024 is shaping up. At the state fair, it was clear why.
content: Iowa was supposed to be fertile ground for Donald Trump’s primary challengers. Its population is disproportionately evangelical, and voters were expected to coalesce around a more faith-driven alternative. But that’s not what’s happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Bob Pardo, Pilot in Daring Rescue in Vietnam War, Dies at 89
description: In an extraordinary act of aerial ballet, he helped a fellow pilot whose plane had become compromised until they could be safely rescued.
content: Bob Pardo, a fighter pilot who during the Vietnam War kept a wingman’s damaged plane aloft in a daring feat of aviation that became known as the Pardo Push, died on Dec. 5 in a hospital near his home in College Station, Texas. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Key Hamas Plotters of Oct. 7 Elude Israel’s Grip on Gaza
description: Israel has battered Gaza in its quest to destroy Hamas, without finding the commanders it has named as its most important targets.
content: Fluttering down from the skies over Gaza on a recent day were clouds of fliers dropped by the Israeli military asking for tips on the whereabouts of top Hamas leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary J. Bass
title: 75 Years Later, Asia’s Wartime Memories Linger
description: The Tokyo war crimes trial is consequential not because of long-defunct Wilsonian daydreams about a world pacified by international law, but because it misfired and fizzled.
content: Seventy-five years ago, around the cold and bleak midnight of Dec. 22-23, 1948, seven convicted Japanese war criminals were marched toward the gallows. Among these former top leaders were Gen. Hideki Tojo, a wartime prime minister found guilty for aggression at Pearl Harbor and for atrocities such as the Burma-Thailand death railway, and Gen. Iwane Matsui, the army commander at Nanjing, who was convicted of failing to prevent the slaughter and mass rape of Chinese there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Gaza Talks Stall, and a Record Wrongful Sentence
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: This Antarctic Octopus Has a Warning About Rising Sea Levels
description: A huge ice sheet appears to have melted about 120,000 years ago, when temperatures were similar to those on Earth today, according to a DNA study that mapped octopus movements.
content: Scientists have long wondered whether the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is a ticking time bomb in terms of sea level rise. New evidence from the DNA of a small octopus that lives in the Southern Ocean suggests that the ice sheet is indeed at risk of collapsing, according to a study published on Thursday in the journal Science.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Hotel Owners Push Back on Merger of National Brands
description: Franchisees are fighting Choice Hotels’ attempted takeover of its biggest rival, which would create a dominant player in the budget hotel sector.
content: When Patrick Pacious, the chief executive of a large portfolio of hotel brands, promoted a blockbuster attempt to acquire a competitor in October, he said the proposed merger would lower costs and attract more customers for the families and small businesses that own most of the company’s locations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Venezuela Renews Claims to Part of Guyana, the Oil-Rich ‘Second Qatar’
description: Venezuela’s territorial claim has been made against leftists and by leftists. It’s been about colonialism, nationalism, Cold War and oil, and it’s complicating U.S. foreign policy.
content: It was the depths of the Cold War in the 1960s, and Caracas was on edge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: ‘Get Out of Our Bus Lanes’: New York’s Message to Drivers
description: The city is cracking down on bus lane enforcement, and agents are calling in tow trucks when drivers can’t be found.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out how a push to keep bus lanes clear is going. We’ll also get details on legislation to limit background checks on prospective tenants in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Shadow
description: What do you think this image is communicating?
content: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rachelle Bonja, Sydney Harper, Rikki Novetsky, Diana Nguyen, Marc Georges, Lynsea Garrison, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Chris Wood
title: The New State of the War in Gaza
description: The accidental killing of three hostages by Israel’s military raises new questions about the fight against Hamas.
content: After the accidental killing of three hostages by Israel’s military, the country’s defense minister appeared to announce a shift in strategy, giving the clearest indication to date of a possible slowing down of the operation in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 21, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Dec. 21, 2023.
content: An article on Tuesday about Russian speakers in Latvia misstated the distance from the Latvian city of Daugavpils to the Russian border. It is about 65 miles, not 15 miles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louise Glück
title: Poem: Primavera
description: Louise Glück’s mode of lamentation was her signature, and it seems fitting that one of her poems occasions the end of this column, after nine years.
content: In “Primavera,” Louise Glück’s fascination with both pastoral scenes and the devastation of loss coalesces in a vision of springtime somewhere, perhaps in a field, where “someone has drawn a picture of the sun.” No one has signed the image; the gesture is anonymous, just as the poet imagines every effort will be at the end of the world. Still, “the artist intends a mood of celebration.” Glück’s mode of lamentation was her signature, and it seems fitting that one of her poems occasions the end of this column, after nine years. The magazine is deeply indebted to its poetry editors — Natasha Trethewey, Matthew Zapruder, Terrance Hayes, Rita Dove, Naomi Shibab Nye, Reginald Dwayne Betts, Victoria Chang and Anne Boyer — for their work curating this column and celebrating the dynamism of life and language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Julia Harris, Jan Ransom and José A. Alvarado Jr
title: Kendra’s Law Was Meant to Prevent Violence. It Failed Hundreds of Times.
description: New York’s premier monitoring program for people with mental illness has broken down repeatedly, including in five cases involving subway shovings.
content: After John Skeene served prison time for beating his mother to death with a chair leg, after he attacked a man with a radiator cover and threatened to murder his therapist, New York State placed him in its gold-standard program for treating mentally ill people at risk of committing violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Travis Diehl
title: Rirkrit Tiravanija: Can Pad Thai Diplomacy Change the World?
description: The artist’s midcareer survey at MoMA PS1 demonstrates the impotence of contemporary art to heal social ills.
content: “Having been labeled as the cook of the art world,” Rirkrit Tiravanija said, “I think people come to see my work expecting to interact.” Indeed, they expect to eat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Caviar Doesn’t Have to Cost a Fortune
description: Here’s where to get a scoop to celebrate the new year. A tip: Skip New Year’s Eve.
content: If you haven’t made reservations for New Year’s Eve by now, you’re probably out of time. I nearly wrote “out of luck,” but stopped myself. I’ve always thought people who eat at home that night are the lucky ones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Why a Warner Bros.-Paramount Merger Does (and Doesn’t) Makes Sense
description: A potential deal could bolster their streaming businesses and negotiating power with cable operators. But their crushing debt load could be a turn-off.
content: Media deal makers aren’t waiting until 2024 to get started on potential big-ticket M.&A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope’s Shift on Gay Couples Followed Quiet Talks and Loud Resistance
description: Pope Francis spoke with L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics and their supporters for years before letting priests bless same-sex couples. But the move’s timing also owed something to its conservative opponents.
content: In March 2021, as stunned L.G.B.T.Q. Catholics grappled with a Vatican document approved by Pope Francis that ruled against blessing same-sex unions, one of his confidants, who is gay, says they spoke on the phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: 6 Months and a Swirl of Controversy: A Timeline of Claudine Gay’s Tenure as Harvard President
description: Since beginning in her role in July, Dr. Gay has come under criticism over the Middle East war and her academic record.
content: Claudine Gay has served as president of Harvard University only since July, but she has faced criticism on two fronts: her response to rising tensions on campus over the Israel-Gaza war, and questions about possible plagiarism in her academic work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Freud’s Last Session’ Review: Film Adaptation and Its Discontents
description: Sigmund Freud and C.S. Lewis probably never met. What the stage-based film presupposes is: Maybe they did?
content: In “Freud’s Last Session,” when the Oxford academic C.S. Lewis (Matthew Goode) arrives late to the London home of Sigmund Freud (Anthony Hopkins), Freud’s chow chow, Jofi, brushes him off. The dog, Freud explains, values punctuality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: New Trump Cases Shadowed by Rocky Relationship With Supreme Court
description: Though he appointed three justices, his administration had the worst track record before the justices since at least the 1930s.
content: “I’m not happy with the Supreme Court,” President Donald J. Trump said on Jan. 6, 2021. “They love to rule against me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Why the Holidays Are a True Test of Your Relationship
description: Making it through the festive month of December is harder than it seems.
content: Philip von Hahn, a 30-year-old tech investor on the Upper East Side, attended a holiday party on Sunday night to take his mind off the recent dissolution of his three-year relationship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Manuela Andreoni
title: The Year in Climate Culture
description: TV shows, movies, books, art exhibits and pop music about our rapidly warming planet.
content: 2023 was a year when climate change felt inescapable. Whether it was the raging wildfires in Canada, the orange skies in New York, the flash floods in Libya or the searing heat in China, the effects of our overheating planet were too severe to ignore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Teens in Search of Birth Control Have Embraced the Hormonal Implant
description: The implant is effective, low-maintenance and relatively pain-free to get.
content: The hormonal implant, a long-acting reversible contraceptive, is an increasingly popular choice among teenagers, according to data published last week from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Just over 13 percent of sexually active teenage girls used the implant between 2015 and 2019, compared with 0.6 percent between 2006 and 2010. This represents the biggest jump in usage compared to all other contraceptive methods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Gaza Deaths Surpass Any Arab Loss in Wars With Israel in Past 40 Years
description: The death toll reported in Gaza has reached roughly 20,000, according to officials in the territory, the heaviest loss on the Arab side in any war with Israel since the 1982 Lebanon invasion.
content: The number of Gaza residents reported killed during Israel’s 10-week-old war in the territory has already surpassed the toll for any other Arab conflict with Israel in more than 40 years and perhaps any since Israel’s founding in 1948.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Best Classical Music Albums of 2023
description: Our favorites include premiere recordings of works by Thomas Adès and Anna Thorvaldsdottir, as well as portraits of Missy Mazzoli and Kaija Saariaho.
content: This recording has so much to applaud: the achievement of Thomas Adès in writing such a clever, vivid, effective work; the ambition of the Los Angeles Philharmonic in performing its hour and a half of music in a single evening and taping it live; the wisdom of Nonesuch in releasing the audio. Essential listening. DAVID ALLEN
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: Coming Soon: A George Santos Documentary Focusing on His ‘Human Side’
description: The filmmaker, Jenner Furst, will pay Mr. Santos an archival material fee, an arrangement similar to the one he used with Billy McFarland, the subject of “Fyre Fraud.”
content: George Santos, the disgraced former congressman trying to parlay his notoriety into a cottage industry, is now participating in a documentary film project on his colorful lies, life and times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Goodman
title: ‘Barbie’ Makes a Strong Showing on Oscar Shortlists
description: The film is the equivalent of a semifinalist in the song, score and sound categories. “Killers of the Flower Moon” also landed on several lists.
content: Will the Oscars also be living in a “Barbie” world when the statuettes are handed out in March? Maybe, if the shortlists in what’s known as below-the-line categories are anything to go by. The academy released the equivalent of semifinalists for best song, documentary and more on Thursday, and “Barbie,” the director Greta Gerwig’s feminist smash, made a strong showing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Housing Aid Safety Net Frays as Rent Costs Rise
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, December 21, 2023.
content: “We’re not just treading water — we’re falling further behind. That was an eye-opener, even for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Alan Feuer
title: Giuliani Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Rudolph Giuliani filed papers in federal bankruptcy court in New York, listing debts including big legal fees, unpaid taxes and the $148 million a jury ordered him to pay two Georgia election workers.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani filed for bankruptcy on Thursday, a day after a federal judge ordered him to start paying the $148 million in damages he owes to two former Georgia election workers for spreading lies that they had tried to steal the 2020 election from Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judge John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the Irresistible Vinaigrette
description: How can he eat his wife’s leftover dressing without being disgusting?
content: Jon writes: I love my wife Tina’s delicious vinaigrette. I use a lot, enough to get all my greens good and juicy. When the salad is gone, a pool of dressing remains. So I raise my plate to my lips like a giant mug and drink. I do this out of sight in the kitchen, but Tina wants me to quit altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: War in Ukraine Has China Cashing In
description: The country’s trade with Russia this year has exceeded $200 billion, and makers of cars and trucks are the big winners.
content: On China’s snowy border with Russia, a dealership that sells trucks has seen its sales double in the past year thanks to Russian customers. China’s exports to its neighbor are so strong that Chinese construction workers built warehouses and 20-story office towers at the border this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: T Magazine’s Favorite Homes of 2023
description: A time portal to the ’80s, a maximalist Italian villa — and more.
content: For this week’s edition of the T List, we’re looking back at some of the most intriguing design stories featured in T this year, from a whimsical ode to the 1980s in St. Louis, lovingly dubbed “the ‘Miami Vice’ house,” to a maximalist villa on Italy’s Lake Como filled with more than 300 oil paintings, among other vast and eclectic collections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr. and Michael M. Weinstein
title: Robert M. Solow, Groundbreaking Economist and Nobelist, Dies at 99
description: His elegant work established that the main determinant of economic growth was technology, not growing capital and labor.
content: Robert M. Solow, who won a Nobel in economic science in 1987 for his theory that advances in technology, rather than increases in capital and labor, have been the primary drivers of economic growth in the United States, died on Thursday at his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Breaking With Postwar History, Japan to Sell Patriot Missiles to U.S.
description: Tokyo appears ready to adjust rules to allow the export of the weapons to the United States, a move that could help Washington support Ukraine’s fight against Russia.
content: Japan is set to announce that it will approve the sale of advanced air defense systems to the United States, a significant shift in its postwar policies restricting the export of weapons and military hardware, and a move that could help Washington support Ukraine in its fight against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone, Jesse Wegman and Jillian Weinberger
title: How Could the Supreme Court Respond to Colorado?
description: Two editorial board writers discuss.
content: Donald Trump engaged in insurrection and that disqualifies him from appearing on the 2024 ballot in Colorado, the state’s Supreme Court ruled Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Tolkien Estate Wins Court Order to Destroy Fan’s ‘Lord of the Rings’ Sequel
description: Ruling that the fan’s unauthorized book violated copyright protections, a judge barred him from distributing it and ordered him to destroy all electronic and physical copies of it.
content: It was supposed to be what a fan described as a “loving homage” to his hero, the author J.R.R. Tolkien, and to “The Lord of the Rings,” which he called “one of the most defining experiences of his life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Patrick Kingsley, Aaron Boxerman and Michael Levenson
title: Gaza Truce Talks Bog Down Over Disputes on Aid Inspections
description: In Cairo and at the U.N., negotiators struggled to come up with plans for pausing the fighting, freeing hostages and speeding up help for Gazans.
content: The top political leader of Hamas was holding talks with Egyptian officials on Wednesday about a possible truce in its war with Israel in the Gaza Strip, as the United Nations Security Council separately worked frantically to craft a resolution to suspend the fighting that would not draw a veto from Israel’s staunchest ally, the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: What We’re Made Of
description: Three new books explore the how, why and what that keep our world moving.
content: Spruce Pine, N.C., is not nearly as famous as Asheville, an epicenter of haute hill culture about an hour’s drive away. But if you were hoping to fill your Instagram feed with Blue Ridge sunsets and bespoke cocktails, be sure to thank the “obscure Appalachian backwater,” as Wired once called Spruce Pine, whose two mines produce the world’s largest supply of an exceptionally pure quartz needed to manufacture the semiconductors in our smartphones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Why Do People File for Bankruptcy?
description: Rudy Giuliani filed for bankruptcy a day after a judge ordered him to start paying $148 million in damages to two former Georgia election workers.
content: The decision by Rudolph W. Giuliani to file for bankruptcy may buy the former New York City mayor some time to deal with his debts — including the $148 million in damages he owes to two former Georgia election workers for spreading lies that they had tried to steal the 2020 election from former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa Wilkinson
title: ‘Aquaman and the Lost Kingdom’ Review: Back With a Trident and Dad Jokes
description: The Atlantean hero-king returns as a new father, a bit worse for wear. But this sequel feels like a film for grown-ups who like fun.
content: I just feel bad for Orm. He’s pompous and strangely boring, but the guy’s heart is basically in the right place. In the first “Aquaman” movie, he was so upset by the surface dwellers (that’s us) who have polluted the seas — the home of his people — that he wanted to unite the armies of Atlantis and punish us. Who could blame him?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Pushes Pro-Police Agenda, With a Big Exception: His Criminal Cases
description: Long a loud supporter of the police, Donald Trump is floating new protections for them. At the same time, he is raging against law enforcement officials who have brought felony charges against him.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has long spoken admiringly of police officers who use aggressive force on the job. For years, he has pointed to his unwavering support for local law enforcement, presenting himself as a “law and order” candidate who would help the police tackle violent crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: U.S. and China Restore Military Dialogue
description: In a video call with his Chinese counterpart, Gen. Charles Q. Brown stressed the importance of communication to reduce tensions.
content: The United States and China restored communications between their two militaries on Thursday, as President Biden’s senior military adviser, Gen. Charles Q. Brown, held a videoconference call with his Chinese counterpart, Gen. Liu Zhenli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Iron Claw’ Review: Body Slams and Broken Lives
description: Zac Efron and Jeremy Allen White play brothers in a melodrama inspired by the wrestling dynasty called the Von Erichs.
content: It doesn’t take long into “The Iron Claw,” a tragicomic melodrama about an American wrestling dynasty, to know that the wildest scenes aren’t going to happen in the ring. They’re going to take place in the family circle, which is evident when the paterfamilias starts listing the order of his favorite sons while they’re chowing down at the breakfast table. It’s weird, though nobody looks as surprised as you feel. Then the writer-director Sean Durkin twists the knife a wee bit more: “The rankings,” the father says brightly, “can always change.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Conti
title: He Has Fished Out Grenades, Bikes and Guns. Can Fame Be Far Behind?
description: All day long, James Kane tosses a giant magnet into New York’s murkiest waters. There’s got to be money in there somewhere.
content: James Kane was not afraid of the grenade. Not even a little bit. But he was feeling a rush of adrenaline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Get That Champagne Feeling on a Sparkling Wine Budget
description: The price of Champagne has risen, but good alternatives are made all over the wine-producing world. They might taste different but they are superb.
content: The holidays require sparkling wine, there’s no getting around that. But does it need to be Champagne?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Anyone but You’ Review: Baring Bums in the Land Down Under
description: Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell romp in a rom-com bomb with gratuitous clothes-shedding, played out against beautiful backdrops.
content: The floundering romantic comedy “Anyone but You” has several things going for it: the rising stars Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell, a luxurious Australian backdrop, and more white teeth and washboard abs than the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue. The plot is a classic switchback prank. Sworn enemies Bea (Sweeney) and Ben (Powell) pretend to fall in love at a destination wedding so that their friends and family (Alexandra Shipp, Hadley Robinson, Bryan Brown, Michelle Hurd and GaTa) will quit trying to trick them into liking each other. It’s a loose reworking of “Much Ado About Nothing,” and, presumably, the first Shakespeare adaptation where a dog does yoga — and certainly the first in which a man (GaTa) serenades a koala. Nevertheless, the film, directed by Will Gluck, who wrote the screenplay with Ilana Wolpert, is so awkwardly assembled that our attention gets pulled away from the leads to the bizarrely lavish buffet spreads in the background. We’re mildly curious about whether these two fakers will slip between the sheets for real — and majorly interested in why a guest bedroom has so many bowls of fruit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Americans Are Signing Up for Obamacare in Record Numbers
description: On December 15 alone, nearly 750,000 people signed up for a plan on HealthCare.gov, the largest single-day total recorded so far.
content: More than 15 million people have signed up for health insurance plans offered on the Affordable Care Act’s federal marketplace, a 33 percent increase compared to the same time last year, according to preliminary data released by the Biden administration on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Friday Briefing: U.N. Prepares to Vote on Gaza Aid
description: Plus, how wealthy was the family in “Home Alone”?
content: After a week of delays, the U.S. held high-level negotiations with Egypt yesterday to find a compromise on a U.N. Security Council resolution that would allow for scaled-up, safe delivery of aid to Gaza, an American official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Just a Housewife? That’s a Dangerous Thought in These Movies.
description: Todd Haynes and Julianne Moore take one of the most overlooked characters in Hollywood and peel back the layers to expose lonely souls and monsters.
content: Near the beginning of Todd Haynes’s new film, “May December,” there’s a moment that has become the subject of fascination. Julianne Moore’s Gracie Atherton-Yoo is preparing for a barbecue. She tells her teenage twins to be careful as they head to the rooftop with friends, and then she goes to the fridge. The music swells. A look of fear crosses her face: “I don’t think we have enough hot dogs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. and Europe Eye Russian Assets to Aid Ukraine as Funding Dries Up
description: Despite legal reservations, policymakers are weighing the consequences of using $300 billion in Russian assets to help Kyiv’s war effort.
content: The Biden administration is quietly signaling new support for seizing more than $300 billion in Russian central bank assets stashed in Western nations, and has begun urgent discussions with allies about using the funds to aid Ukraine’s war effort at a moment when financial support is waning, according to senior American and European officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: vertiginous
description: This word has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word vertiginous has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 26 in “PinkPantheress’s Music Broke the Internet. Up Next? Everything Else” by Lindsay Zoladz:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hurdles Facing Offshore Wind Farms
description: Readers discuss the causes of the delays and cancellations. Also: Pope’s blessing of gay couples; the term “Bidenomics”; employing caregivers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Our Semicolons, Ourselves
description: A.I. or no A.I., it pays to write — and to write well.
content: When I go through students’ papers and flag the misplaced modifiers, note the clichés or explain that a 15-sentence paragraph is less approachable than a five-sentence one, I sometimes ask myself a question that the students who get those papers back from me perhaps ponder as well: Does it really matter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Topics Suppressed in China Are Underrepresented on TikTok, Study Says
description: The report, from the Network Contagion Research Institute at Rutgers University, could raise new concerns about whether Beijing influences the content on the popular video app.
content: Topics often suppressed by the Chinese government within its borders, including Tibet, Hong Kong protests and the Uyghur population, appear to be unusually underrepresented on TikTok compared with Instagram, according to a report published Thursday by online researchers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Rosenberg
title: Now, Black Figures Have a Name, a Frame and a Show
description: A vital American Folk Art Museum show reckons with centuries of erasure by uncovering historical records of the unnamed Black people depicted in artwork.
content: Even as New York’s museums deliver a season of exhibitions in which the Black figure is emphatically, profoundly present, these institutions are reckoning with legacies of absence, invisibility and anonymity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Sarah Kliff
title: N.Y. Health Dept. Is Looking Into Bellevue’s Weight-Loss Surgery Program
description: The Health Dept. is looking into the public hospital’s use of unlicensed technicians during some bariatric surgeries.
content: The New York State Department of Health is scrutinizing Bellevue Hospital’s use of unlicensed technicians to assist doctors in weight-loss surgeries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Cooking
title: A Whole Roasted Squash With Tomato-Ginger Chickpeas for a Fuss-Free Feast
description: And lechon kawali and garlic-braised short ribs, if you feel like showing off a bit.
content: There’s a lot to love about this time of year — lights everywhere, kids in cute sweaters, never-ending cookies. But one of the best parts of the season is how any dinner, not just the ones falling on the calendar holidays, can feel so festive, joyful and generous. Invite friends over on a whim and make Ali Slagle’s new whole roasted squash with tomato-ginger chickpeas, which is both incredibly picturesque and very easy: Robust kabocha squash is roasted whole and then split into greedy chunks, which then hammock the jammy tomatoes and chickpeas that have roasted alongside the squash. Ask one friend to bring beverages, another to pick up a pint of ice cream to go with the aforementioned cookies, and poof — a sweet, cozy holiday party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: The Army Said Tank Blasts Don’t Harm Troops. His Case Raises Doubts.
description: Researchers say troops’ brains may be injured by blasts from firing M1 Abrams tank guns and other weapons, even if they measure below the Pentagon’s ceiling for safe exposure.
content: Christian Beyer worked around the ground-shaking blasts of one of the Army’s most powerful weapons — the M1 Abrams tank — for 23 years. And for nearly all that time, he was a model soldier, given awards for meritorious service and promoted all the way up to master sergeant in charge of training young tank crews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Israeli Military Uncovers New Evidence About Hostage Deaths in Gaza
description: Israel’s military has been quick in disclosing details of the fatal shooting of the three hostages, who were unarmed and bearing a makeshift white flag. The shooting, it said, violated its rules of engagement.
content: Israel’s military said it has learned that its forces had come close to finding three hostages before they were mistakenly killed by Israeli troops in Gaza last week, an episode that has roiled the country and raised pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to quickly reach a deal to free Hamas’s remaining captives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Judge Orders Giuliani to Pay $148 Million Damage Award Immediately
description: A federal judge found that Rudolph Giuliani had a history of hiding assets and that he must swiftly pay two Georgia election workers he was found to have defamed.
content: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered Rudolph W. Giuliani to immediately pay the $148 million he owes to two former Georgia election workers for falsely accusing them of manipulating ballots after the 2020 election, citing concerns that he might “conceal his assets” if he were allowed to wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross and Aurelien Breeden
title: Channel Tunnel Reopens After Surprise Strike by Railway Workers Ends
description: Many trains traveling between London and continental Europe had been canceled on Thursday because of an unexpected walkout, causing hours of chaos just days before Christmas.
content: Rail traffic under the English Channel was gradually returning to normal on Thursday after the end of an unexpected walkout by railway workers that had blocked the Channel Tunnel, stranding passengers and causing several hours of travel chaos just days before Christmas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
description: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, on the Upper West Side and in Hunters Point.
content: A one-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath, roughly 1,000-square-foot apartment that has a windowed kitchen with marble countertops, a large living and dining area, a primary suite with a walk-in closet, windowed bathrooms, a wood-burning fireplace and casement windows, on the fifth floor of a 10-story prewar doorman building with a resident manager, a live-in super, shared laundry, a gym, a children’s playroom, a bike room, a garden, a waiting list for basement storage cages and a roof deck. Emily Beare, Beth Doud and Lexi Alper, 212-726-0786, CORE NYC; corenyc.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: ‘Home Alone 2’ Fans Can Buy This Four-Story Slice of Movie History
description: OK, the Manhattan brownstone, now on the market for $6.7 million, wasn’t actually in the 1992 film. But it is where Kevin McCallister took on the Wet Bandits.
content: When Kevin McCallister (Macaulay Culkin) gets chased out of The Plaza in the 1992 film “Home Alone 2,” he heads across town to the Upper West Side, where his Uncle Rob has a brownstone at 51 West 95th Street. But Uncle Rob is out of town, the house is under construction and Kevin is, yet again, on his own to fend off bandits Harry and Marv (Joe Pesci and Daniel Stern).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Keep Hoping It’s Curtains for Trump. He’s Still Center Stage.
description: As Donald Trump faces a new threat to his political future, this time over the question of ballot eligibility, Democrats again find themselves looking toward American institutions to stop him.
content: For as long as Donald J. Trump has dominated Republican politics, many Democrats have pined for a magical cure-all to rid them of his presence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Inner Cage’ Review: The Leftovers
description: In this solemn Italian drama, the guards and inmates of a decommissioned prison renegotiate the limits of power.
content: Is there anything more quintessentially Italian than solving differences over a hearty plate of pasta and a glass of wine? Not as far as “The Inner Cage” is concerned, a ponderous prison drama that teeters on the verge of violence right up until one of the inmates gets to cooking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: DeSantis Says Trump’s Indictments ‘Sucked Out All the Oxygen’ From Primary
description: Ron DeSantis seemed to acknowledge that the former president’s legal woes were making it harder for his rivals to break through in the Republican primary.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida said that the indictments of former President Donald J. Trump had “distorted” the Republican presidential primary, tacitly admitting that the former president’s legal problems have helped him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Pop-Punk Has Long Been Funny, but Who Gets to Make the Jokes?
description: Blink-182’s childish humor felt out of step with the times this year, as Olivia Rodrigo and 100 gecs released thrilling, hilarious music that talks back to — and erases — old stereotypes.
content: “Turn This Off!” is a pummeling, 23-second novelty song on “One More Time,” the most recent album from the pop-punk juggernaut Blink-182, and the first in 12 years to feature the singer and guitarist Tom DeLonge. “If you’re too offended by these words,” DeLonge shouts in his vowely, oft-imitated Southern California drawl, “then please [expletive] off.” His rapid-fire verse concludes in a crude joke, perhaps the only word of which I can quote in this publication is “proctologists.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Sheelagh McNeill
title: Excerpts From Dr. Claudine Gay’s Work
description: Here are five examples of work by President Claudine Gay of Harvard that have been spotlighted by critics who have accused her of plagiarism.
content: Harvard’s president, Dr. Claudine Gay,  is accused of lifting words, phrases and sentences from other sources without proper attribution. Most, if not all, of the examples below are written in technical and academic jargon, not meant to convey sweeping or original ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elyssa Dudley, Lynn Levy and Daniel Ramirez
title: Our Critics on the Conducting in ‘Maestro’
description: Bradley Cooper did his homework.
content: Our classical music critics dissect Bradley Cooper’s performance as the famed conductor Leonard Bernstein in the new film “Maestro.” In his meticulous recreation of a 1973 concert, Cooper captures each sweep of the baton, each enraptured facial expression and each little bead of sweat. But Cooper’s film leaves out the criticism Bernstein received for his over-the-top conducting style, including some choice words from The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Storm Inundates Homes and Roads in Ventura County, Calif.
description: Parts of Ventura County were evacuated after a month’s worth of rain fell in one hour early Thursday. The rain was expected to continue in Southern California through Friday evening.
content: Parts of Ventura County, Calif., were evacuated early Thursday as heavy rainfall inundated roads and homes in the region, local authorities said, while forecasters warned that the storm would continue to pummel parts of Southern California through Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1898: Russia and the Red Sea
description: A report from Berlin indicated that Moscow was planning to build a railway connecting Russia with the Red Sea.
content: BERLIN, MONDAY — The following curious notice appears in a Berlin paper: “It’s said that Russian officials holding a high position in their own country are now on a secret mission in England, where they have been negotiating for the last month with officials in the British Civil Service.” Their alleged object is to obtain information, maps and plans concerning English concessions in Persia and Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: W.H.O. Describes Grim Scenes at Hospitals in Gaza’s North
description: Northern Gaza has no more functioning hospitals, the director general of the World Health Organization has said.
content: Northern Gaza has no more functioning hospitals, the director general of the World Health Organization said, describing scenes of horror witnessed by aid workers in the ruins of two partially destroyed medical facilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Cheers Colorado for ‘Illegalizing’ Trump
description: Fallon joked that before the court ruling on Tuesday, “Trump thought ‘the insurrection clause’ was one of those Tim Allen movies on Disney+.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins, Jenny Gross and Aric Toler
title: At Least 15 Dead in Czech Republic After Shooting at Prague University
description: The police said the suspect, who also died, first shot his father in a town outside Prague and then continued his rampage at the university.
content: Fourteen people were killed and more than 20 others wounded in a shooting rampage at Charles University in the Czech Republic on Thursday, the authorities said. The gunman, a 24-year-old student in world history at the university, also killed himself after the shooting spree in central Prague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson
title: U.S. Says It’s Ready to Back U.N. Resolution to Allow More Aid Into Gaza
description: The timing for a vote on the Security Council resolution was unclear. Diplomats were focused on who would oversee the inspection of aid entering the enclave.
content: After nearly a week of intense negotiations, the United States said on Thursday night that it was ready to support a United Nations Security Council resolution that would call for more desperately needed aid to enter the Gaza Strip. A vote was not expected until Friday at the earliest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! It’s Almost 2024 and Travelers Keep Making the Same Mistakes.
description: Our columnist begs you to avoid middlemen, get promises in writing and stop expecting perfection in an imperfect world.
content: Seth here — writing to you to gripe this time, rather than the other way around. The Tripped Up column helps travelers with problems they encounter (and sometimes even wrangles refunds), but no matter how much great advice I give, readers keep making the same mistakes! It’s almost as if you prioritize your families, jobs and health over memorizing my suggestions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Westbrook and Emily Holzknecht
title: The Life Span of Loneliness
description: Times readers, ages 16 to 93, open up about feeling alone.
content: The Opinion video above gives voice to the lonely. We are publishing it at the end of a year in which loneliness started getting the kind of attention it has long deserved — an effort led, in large part, by the surgeon general of the United States, Dr. Vivek Murthy. In a guest essay last spring, he revealed that he, too, had struggled with loneliness and said the nation was facing “an epidemic of loneliness and isolation.” Several days later, he issued a surgeon general advisory about the problem, calling it a “public health crisis” and outlining a strategy to confront it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and a six-bedroom in Hopewell, N.J.
content: A six-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath, multi-wing house built in 1860 and expanded to include formal living and dining rooms, a great room, an updated kitchen, a library, a guest wing with a separate entrance and a finished basement with a game room and wine cellar, plus two detached garages for six cars, a barn and a dollhouse, on 31.4 acres. Jane Henderson Kenyon, Callaway Henderson, Sotheby’s International Realty, 609-828-1450, sothebysrealty.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Read
title: The Year Millennials Aged Out of the Internet
description: It is the zoomers’ web now.
content: For my entire professional life, I have started nearly every weekday morning with an extremely important productivity ritual: I make a coffee, I sit down at my computer, and I mess around on the internet for an hour or so. And, for most of my career as a writer, this has been an effortless task. I’ve had accounts on dozens of social networks, message boards and online communities thronging with similarly bored and truant peers, vibrant with creativity and delight. Or, at least, with tolerably decent jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: France’s President Condemns ‘Manhunt’ Against Gérard Depardieu
description: Emmanuel Macron broke with his culture minister, who had called comments made by Depardieu in a documentary a “disgrace.” The actor is facing renewed scrutiny over sexual assault accusations.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France this week condemned what he called a “manhunt” targeting Gérard Depardieu, the embattled French actor whose worldwide fame has been tarnished in recent years by allegations of sexual harassment and assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Vin Diesel Is Accused of Sexually Assaulting a Former Assistant
description: The assistant filed a lawsuit saying that the actor had groped her and forcibly kissed her in a hotel room in 2010. The actor denied the allegations.
content: A former assistant to Vin Diesel, one of Hollywood’s most bankable action stars, filed a sexual battery lawsuit against the actor on Thursday, saying that he groped her and pinned her against the wall of an Atlanta hotel room during the filming of the fifth “Fast & Furious” movie in 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: The Super Mega Support Group
description: Want to discuss or get help with Puzzle Mania’s huge crossword? Here’s where to go.
content: When readers receive their annual copy of Puzzle Mania in the Sunday edition of The New York Times, very often their first thought is, How am I going to get this done? We offered some helpful ways to approach this humongous labor of love in this article, but we asked that no one post any spoilers in the comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By T.M. Brown
title: From Harlem to Central Brooklyn With $500,000: Would It Be Enough for a Two-Bedroom?
description: Two first-time buyers discovered that the co-ops in Brooklyn were bigger, but the condos were nicer.
content: Two first-time buyers discovered that the co-ops in Brooklyn were bigger, but the condos were nicer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ferren
title: 36 Hours in Córdoba, Spain
description: Meet history at every turn in this southern Spanish city with Roman ruins, spectacular Moorish architecture and a Jewish quarter with picturesque alleys.
content: Meet history at every turn in this southern Spanish city with Roman ruins, spectacular Moorish architecture and a Jewish quarter with picturesque alleys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Hogan, Brent McDonald and Jonathan Weisman
title: Times/Siena Poll Finds Wide Disapproval of Biden on Gaza
description: The Times’ Jonathan Weisman analyzed a New York Times/Siena College poll which found that voters broadly disapprove of the way President Biden is handling the bloody strife between Israelis and Palestinians.
content: The Times’ Jonathan Weisman analyzed a New York Times/Siena College poll which found that voters broadly disapprove of the way President Biden is handling the bloody strife between Israelis and Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Westbrook and Emily Holzknecht
title: The Life Span of Loneliness
description: Times readers, ages 16 to 93, open up about loneliness.
content: Times readers, ages 16 to 93, open up about loneliness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr, Carmit Hoomash, Caroline Kim and David Blumenfeld
title: ‘There Was No Sense of Time’: Israeli Teen Recounts Captivity in Gaza
description: Sahar Kalderon, 16, was abducted from Kibbutz Nir Oz on Oct. 7. Her father and 12-year-old brother were also kidnapped. The siblings were released on Nov. 27 as part of a cease-fire deal. Their father remains in captivity.
content: Sahar Kalderon, 16, was abducted from Kibbutz Nir Oz on Oct. 7. Her father and 12-year-old brother were also kidnapped. The siblings were released on Nov. 27 as part of a cease-fire deal. Their father remains in captivity.
source.name: The New York Times
